title: Robo-dog goes walkies as Boston Dynamics put their military mega-mutt through basic training with US marines
text:
Being dropped into the middle of a combat zone might be easier to deal with if you had your faithful robot dog by your side .
Thankfully, the Google-owned military company Boston Dynamics has developed just such a companion, and it's called Spot.
The 70kg, quadruped robot is controlled by remote control from up to 500 meters away. It walks on four hydraulically-actuated legs.
DOD The robot can be controlled from up to 500 meters away
It also features a Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) laser imaging sensor - similar to the ones Google puts on its self-driving cars .
The US military has previously talked about using robots in battle situations to carry heavy equipment out in the field - or scout for IEDs. A bit like a lethal game of fetch.
"We want to continue to experiment with quadruped technology and find ways that this can be employed to enhance the Marine Corps warfighting capabilties," said Capt. James Pineiro, the branch head for Marine Corps Warfighting Lab.
Spot is electronically powered, as opposed to the gas powered engine that runs both BigDog and Boston Dynamic's other pet-like robot, LS3.
DOD Spot the robot dog during training
Spot can canter along next to a human, climb stairs and walk off-road.
Most impressively, it can even maintain balance when knocked by a human or obstacle.
On-board sensors work quickly to stop it from falling over should it, for example, trip up while out in the field.
